Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2008 02:16PM anitach wrote: Hi Sunny,  I started on Taxotere, Cytoxin and Herceptin last May and always got what I called the "Chemo Flush" with every treatment. My face, neck and chest looked like I had a sunburn every time. It usually went away within 2 days. I did actually have an allergice reaction on my 4th taxotere treatment where my throat started to close up and I actually passed out for a minute in the middle of the infusion so they switched me to Abraxane which was a lot easier to handle for me. However, even with the Abraxane I still got the Chemo Flush.... I think it is a side effect of all the taxanes.  Hope this helps and you are doing well with the treatments. Anita

I went ahead and finished 5 more rounds of chemo and was still NED as of Jan. '08. I am now on Herceptin only. Anita

Posts.Content: anitach wrote: Hi Ladies, I just finished chemo (Abraxane) on 12/27 and started taking Herceptin on the 3-week schedule as opposed to the 1-week schedule that I was doing while on chemo. I am wondering how long it takes to feel back to "normal". I told my husband just last week that I still feel like I'm on chemo. I'm fatigued and still feel that kind of achiness that I can't describe to people but I know you women know what I'm talking about. I have been taking a 7.5 mg Lortab every evening after work to get help me enjoy my family time in the evenings. I'm afraid now that I am addicted to the Lortab. I just wish I felt "good" again and wonder if it will ever happen. BTW, I am Stage IV with mets to lymph nodes and will probably be on Herceptin forever. I keep hoping that this feeling is just residual from chemo and not due to the Herceptin. Is anyone else feeling like me??? Dx 5/1/2007, IDC, <1cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2008 10:37AM anitach wrote: ejlj, I notice on your signature that you were dx in April. What kind of treatments are you taking? I can tell you that I am about a year ahead of you in dx and when I was on chemo I would have all sorts of wierd symptoms all the time... after a while I just got used to it. I wouldn't worry about this now if I hadn't felt the lump. I do know though that the wise ladies on this board always say if it bothers you for more than two weeks continuously you should tell your onc. I actually just saw a whole thread on the HER2 board about headaches and migraines during treatment. You might want to check that out. As for doing silly things... I can barely remember my name on some days, I think it is just chemo brain. I'll be keeping my fingers crossed that that is all it is for you as well. How old are your kids? Mine are 11, 8, and 4.
Posts.Title: enlarged nodes in neck anitach toyful

Posts.Content: anitach wrote: I am scared to death right now and really need someone to talk me out of this tree. About three weeks ago I started having a pain on my left side starting in my neck and going all the way down and across my collar bone. I told my onc. about it the Thursday before last but he didn't feel anything. I never could pinpoint the pain so I thought it must be a pinched nerve. When I went shopping it got worse, I guess from carrying bags, but then about the middle of last week I didn't notice any pain anymore. I have had a cold with a lot of sinus and chest congestion for over a week. A few days ago I was feeling all over my neck again just in case and found a tiny lump on the left side of my neck. At first I thought I was just rolling a tendon but then I could definitely tell it was like a marble rolling under my fingers. It is about the size of a pea. Then yesterday I was feeling more and found another one similar in size right above my right collarbone. I have been NED since Aug. '07 and now I'm scared to death this is a recurrence. I can't believe the Herceptin has stopped working for me. Please someone tell me this could be anything but cancer. I'm so scared. Has anyone else had enlarged nodes that caused pain? Please someone help me. Anita  Dx 5/1/2007, IDC, <1cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Tingling spot in back evieo mye

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2009 03:25PM anitach wrote: I'm not sure how or why it broke off but I am concerned that it did. I'm considering contacting the manufacturer because if some were defective or something I would like for those with the same kind to be aware of what could happen. I know it was still attached 4 weeks ago when I had my last treatment but the Drs. are certain that it was causing those heart palpitations so it had to have happened at least a week ago. Again, just so thankful to God that it was caught before I had a heart attack or threw a clot!! Mason, I don't know if I'm "destined for greatness" but I like to think that I am destined to see my children grow up!!! LuAnn - I was awake while they went in.... absolutely surreal!! I was looking at the xray screen and saw the piece and it was like moving back and forth. I asked the nurse if that was the piece and why was it moving around like that.... she informed it was beating with my heart!!!! Needless to say I was gung ho for them going through any orifice they needed to get that thing out. Pee - although I know my story is a scary one I truly don't want it to discourage you from getting a port. I have had mine since May '07 and until this past treatment it served me well. Watson is 100% right when she tells you that my case is rare. Since I'm only on Herceptin right now every 3 weeks I won't get the port replaced; however, even after this episode, if I ever need chemo again (please pray that I won't!) I wouldn't hesitate to get another port. If anything I just would like my story to encourage all of us to be extra diligent about our symptoms and warning signs. Who gives a crap if anyone thinks we have canceritis!! We are now delicate treasures and we have earned the right to be treated as such!! Thanking God..... Anita
Posts.Title: Another bump in the road (Sorry it's a long one) anitach sydpen2

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2008 11:02AM anitach wrote: I started Abraxane in May'07 and had to get the buzz cut by the middle of July. I finally shaved it to the scalp just to see how it would come back and low and behold my previous head of superfine super straight hair has come back super thick and curly! My hair started growing back almost immediately too after I shaved it completely. By Halloween I had the GI Jane look. Overall, I found Abraxane a LOT easier to handle than the taxotere especially with the body aches. I don't really understand why they even give Taxotere instead of Abraxane since you don't need the premeds and the body seems to handle it better? Anita
Posts.Title: Abraxane and hair loss bevnurse Kasey

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2010 11:08AM anitach wrote: KLee, First off so sorry for all the pain you are experiencing right now. I am on neratinib and just had my nipple reconstruction a few weeks ago and the pain was almost unbearable up until the last couple of days. I think when you are on a chemo treatment having surgery is ten times harder on your body. When I first started chemo they started my out on cytoxin and taxotere. During my fourth infusion of taxotere I had an allergic reaction to the taxotere. My throat started closing up and I passed out for a minute. After that my insurance agreed to pay for the abraxane. Even after just the four doses of the taxotere I can tell you without a doubt that the abraxane is MUCH easier than the taxotere. Still lose your hair but the fatigue and joint pain were much less severe. I would fight hard for the abraxane if I were you.' Wishing you the best and hoping you have pain free days soon!! Anita
Posts.Title: Am getting pretty depressed... KLee Fidelia

Posts.Content: anitach wrote: As of today I will have been on Herceptin for 2 years for mets to mediastinal node. I have been NED since Aug. '07. I met with my onc. this morning and he thought I should go ahead and take a break from the treatment for a while if I am still NED. I have decided that if I am still NED I want to go ahead with a double mastectomy. I know this a controversial subject but I really feel strongly that it is the right choice for me. I am not denying that I am Stage IV but I can't help but feel the "what ifs" creeping in on me all the time. I think I spent the first year of my dx with my head in the sand trying to pretend like it wasn't happening to me and then the second year I was so thankful to God for the healing that I didn't even want to think about rocking the boat! Now I have an overwhelming urge to try to take back control of my body and health and I really feel like the mx will help me with that. Even if it does come back (I know there are several that are going to say it WILL come back) at least I will have the peace of mind of knowing I did everything in my power to stop it. I had to do a little arm twisting with my onc. but I think he is on board now. So I will have a PET in 3 weeks and if all is still well I will be meeting with a surgeon in Nashville. Does anyone have any advice on the type of surgery I should have or the best surgeons and PS in Nashville? Anita Dx 5/1/2007, IDC, <1cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: New plan of action anitach rkt

Posts.Content: anitach wrote: So Thursday will go down as a day from hell for me. Please bear with me, I'll try to make this fiasco as short as possible, but I really need to share. I am on Herceptin every 3 weeks.... I go in Thursday morning for my Herceptin treatment. Because we have had a major ice storm here I actually hadn't had a treatment in 4 weeks. The treatment room was packed and I usually go straight from there to work so I seriously considered leaving and rescheduling for the next week. Just as that thought crossed my mind they called me back..... the first preemptive strike by the angel on my shoulder! The nurse sticks my port as usual but when she does it is unusually painful and blood squirts into the syringe immediately. She notices that the blood is brown indicating that it seems old. She tries to push the syringe to flush the port and I feel a pressure in the cath in my chest like it is going to blow. She calls over the more experienced nurse who determines that they should not touch the port anymore (preemptive strike #2!) and starts the infusion in my arm. Luckily the surgeon that put my port in is right across the hall so I go over to his office as soon as my Herceptin infusion is done. He determines that the port needs to just come out and proceeds to do that right there in his office with some numbing medication (still OUCH!). So after he gets the port out I asked him what was wrong with it. He says he doesn't see anything wrong with it and they flushed it out just fine.... that didn't seem right to me. I get dressed and am on my way out the door to go to work. Just as I get to the door he calls out my name to come back (preemptive strike #3!). He notices that the catheter that he pulled out was slightly jagged on the end, he worries that part of it may have broken off. Sends me over for an xray. I have the xray and go back to his office to wait. He calls me into his office and shows that there is indeed a piece of catheter broken off of the port. Only it's not just a little piece - it is in fact 12 cm long and it is in my HEART!!! He calls my cardiologist who wants me transported to Vanderbilt in Nashville via ambulance to remove the cath from my heart immediately. In Nashville they do a procedure where they went through my femural artery up to my heart and fished the cath out with a "hook". I stayed overnight for observation and am now home and portless. Needless to say, I am just feeling so very fortunate that the cath was found the easy way via xray as opposed to the hard way - heart attack or pulmonary embolism! The nearly 6 inch piece of catheter was in my left atrium and pulmonary artery. Today I am just very sore in my chest where the port was. Last week I had started having heart palpitations but I chalked them up to anxiety from the power outage and ice storm that we had here. I guess this just serves as yet another reminder to listen to our bodies and not take any chances... if you all are like me you get tired of constantly telling a doctor or nurse of all our aches and pains and feel like you are being a hypochondriac. That is why I didn't go to the Dr. about the heart palpitations.... I didn't want to be a complainer!! The bottom line for me today is I praise God (HE is able tripleneg!!) and for one more day am so so happy to be alive!!! Anita Dx 5/1/2007, IDC, <1cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: tired, tired, tired motherof5 MJLToday

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2008 09:06AM anitach wrote: Beth,  I am really glad you brought this up because it has been a point of contention and doubt for me since my diagnosis. I was diagnosed in May '07 at the age of 35 with IDC and mets to axillary, subclavicular, intermammary, and one mediastinal lymph node. They told me that the mediastinal node made me a Stage IV. After 3 round of chemo with Herceptin a PET scan showed me to be NED. I finished 5 more rounds of chemo and another PET scan in January showed still NED. I am now on Herceptin only for at least another year. I always thought from the beginning that if the cancer went away that I would be looking at having a mastectomy. However, after the second NED report came back my onc decided that there was not reason to remove "healthy breast" or radiate "healthy nodes". I still am not sure about this decision. I know some say that there is no point in surgery for a Stave IV patient but since I am NED I wonder if it could still benefit me, especially since my Mets were confined to lymph nodes. Any input or opinions from you knowledgeable ladies out there would be great.... Anita

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2008 12:41PM anitach wrote: I was originally diagnosed at Stage IV as well but no tissue damage, just lymph node involvement. Originally, my Dr. said that they would do masectomy and radiation but after 2 Pet scans that showed me to be NED he changed his mind and said that as long as there is no activity showing on PET he things we should just leave everything alone. I am now on Herceptin only. I still worry a little about the decision - like am I asking for a reoccurance by not having my breasts removed? But then again I understand my Dr's. reasoning that there really is nothing to remove, ie. no tumor to take out anymore! So for now I'm going to go with that!
Posts.Title: Surgery 30something anitach

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 10:36AM anitach wrote: Heather, I was on Cytoxin, Taxotere, and HErceptin for 8 months and my periods never stopped. I thought that was a kick in the teeth too..... I lost my hair but not my periods!! However, I am Er/PR- so the doctors never were concerned about it. They said that my body is hard to trick. You being hormone positive might be a problem since estrogen may affect your cancer. I know a lot of women who are ER+ have an oopherectomey to have their ovaries removed. It might be something for you to look into. Hoping for lots of luck in treatment coming your way!  Anita
Posts.Title: Taxotere and that lovely little thing called a period heatherpalmerton God-is-good

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2007 12:18PM anitach wrote: Joan, I was dx in May '07 with met to lymph nodes. I started on Cytoxin, Taxotere, and Herceptin in May. I had an allergic reaction to the Taxotere after 3 treatments so they switched me to Abraxane. I found the Abraxane to be a lot easier to handle than the Taxotere. No steroids, a lot less joint pain and fatigue. I got my treatments on Thursdays and usually would feel pretty fatigued starting Saturday night and all day Sunday. The rest of the week felt pretty good actually. I never even had to miss a day of work through the 8 rounds of treatment. It did take a while for my hair to fall out as well and I actually went ahead and shaved before it all came out as it was getting in my food. I actually shaved it in July and it started growing back in September. My head is now completely covered with hair and is about a 1/2 inch long, maybe a little longer in some places. Came back wavy too so that is a plus!! Another side effect I had from the Abraxane was what I call the chemo flush. My face and chest were always beat red the day after treatment but would go away my Saturday. Oh yeah, I forgot to mention that after 3 rounds of treatment my PET came back NED! I wish you the best and know that you can beat this thing!!
